{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3593033,"name":null,"username":"Betaloop","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/2bfe46/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-15T13:48:25.797Z","cooked":"

I’m trying to simulate an elevator on a pivot in wpilib, but it seems to me that the elevator sim class only supports upright elevators. Is there any way to simulate this using the elevator sim class? and if not how should i go about doing it?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-04-15T13:48:25.797Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":31,"reads":273,"readers_count":272,"score":209.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":499407,"topic_slug":"pivoting-elevator-simulation","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65566,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pivoting-elevator-simulation/499407/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3593419,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-15T21:04:38.005Z","cooked":"

As far as I can tell, the ElevatorSim class does not support an elevator that is tilted statically or dynamically. If I was trying to do this (and I have not tried), I would subclass ElevatorSim and modify updateX so the gravity compensation included the angle of the elevator. If the angle was fixed, gravity compensation might look like:

xdot = xdot.plus(VecBuilder.fill(
    0,
    -9.8 * Math.sin(kAngleRadFromHoriz)));

If the angle was dynamic, the changing, current angle would need to provided by a supplier and gravity compensation might look like:

xdot = xdot.plus(VecBuilder.fill(
    0,
    -9.8 * Math.sin(angleRadFromHorizSupplier.getAsDouble())));

Of course, if you were also trying to simulate the pivot of the “arm” that is the elevator, the SingleJointedArmSim would now have to be modified to accomodate the changing arm length as the elevator extends and retracts. A better way handle these interactions between elevator angle and arm length would be to create a new system that includes both the elevator and arm components in one model. However, such a system may not be representable by the LinearSystemSim class. You’d probably have to make a custom model and do numerical integration on that…a non-trival task for sure.
